thread.title: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will outline plans for a 'Bank of the North' at Sunderland rally
thread.title_full: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will outline plans for a 'Bank of the North' at Sunderland rally

author: Michael Muncaster
title: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will outline plans for a 'Bank of the North' at Sunderland rally
text:
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will outline plans for a 'Bank of the North' at Sunderland rally 05:30, 12 Aug 2016 Labour wants to set up a National Investment Bank and a network of regional banks to ensure the north of England receives investment Shares Get daily news by email Danny Lawson/PA Wire Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn arrives ahead of a Labour leadership hustings at the Hilton Newcastle Gateshead hotel 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will today outline plans for a “Bank of the North” to ensure every part of the north of England receives investment. 
Mr Corbyn will be speaking at a rally in Sunderland where he will reaffirm the party’s version to “unlock” £500 billion of investment for businesses. 
Labour wants to set up a National Investment Bank and a network of regional banks to “rebuild Britain’s industries after years of neglect”. 
The aim would be to encourage private sector investment in businesses to help create 100,000 additional well-paid, secure jobs across the North East. 
Mr Corbyn said it would help “left behind” communities which voted to leave the European Union and who feel they have been forgotten by successive governments. Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
He said: “Under my leadership, a Labour Government will create a ‘Bank of the North’ so that no community in the North is left behind. 
“This would help to deliver infrastructure, manufacturing and new industries backed up by a publicly-owned National Investment Bank and regional banks. 
“Our plan is to build a high skilled, high tech, low carbon economy which has the potential to unlock 100,000 additional secure jobs across the North East.” 
Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell has previously spoken in favour of the plans and claimed regions such as the North East would be hit hardest by leaving the EU. 
He said: “The North-East exports more goods to the EU than any other English region, per head of population. 
“It also receives more EU structural funding support than any other English region. 
“The Government needs to tell us, now, what it’s going to do to stop North East’s trade relationships being damaged by Brexit.” 
The Jeremy for Labour rally will take place in Keel Square, Sunderland, from 11.30am to 1pm. Labour Party in crisis
